turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What do you suppose anybody wants? Money, money, money!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Listen, I told you I wasn't interested in that deal, didn't I?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I want to know why .

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Tom, I never had trouble getting credit from you before. When I was flat broke you gave me all the money I wanted. Now I come to you with a swell deal, and the greatest

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I'll tell you why. I don't like the crowd you're mixed up with.  Personally, you can have all the credit you want. But for that deal - not a cent.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But listen, Tom, I

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What's the idea of turning her down? It sounds like a perfectly safe investment.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: She's a widow. I don't like taking mortgages from widows.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: If she can't pay, I'll have to foreclose, won't I?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yes - sure

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Yeah - sure!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oscar, what's the matter?

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: I was the first one to see it. I was coming down the stairs, and there was the watchman lying dead at my feet.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No kidding?

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: No kidding. When I saw it, you could'a knocked me over with a pin.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Where's Matt?

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: Matt?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah. He'll have a tough time thinking up a wise-crack for this one . . .

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: The detectives got Matt up there in Sampson's office.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: He has?

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Say Matt, I'll have to have some money for those Manville payrolls.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: About twenty-four thousand.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: It was more than that last week.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Here's twenty-five thousand.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Say, do me a favor, will you Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Let me have ten bucks?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Ten bucks? Say, if I had ten bucks, I'd quit.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Charlie!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I'll pay it back to you Saturday - on the level I will. Give a guy a break, will you? I've got to get it back in my account. If Helen ever finds out that I

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Baby, I can't give you anything but love...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Whose death?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: It'll be yours if you don't kick in with that ten bucks.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Say pal, did you ever hear of a Depression?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Aw, nerts!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Where you been?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Where do you think I've been?  I took the baby for a stroll in the park.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: What's the matter, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'm fourteen cents out, and it took me half an hour to find the mistake. And me with a date, too.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I remember once when your account checked.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: And listen, wise guy - I'm setting friend time clock for exactly nine o'clock, so no squawks out of you guys in the morning.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Say, don't annoy me. I got troubles of my own.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Mr. Dickson in yet?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Not yet, Mr. Clark.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: When he comes in, tell him we're waiting for him in the board room.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: And tell him not to delay.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Personally, I think you're getting panic-stricken about nothing. Dickson's all right.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Oh, is he? We carry more unsecured paper than any other institution in the city. We're fools to tolerate it.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Don't make me laugh, Schultz!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Dickson doesn't have to go. But he must agree to this merger with New York Trust

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What good will that do?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: What good will that do?  Why, it will take control away from him. We'll put somebody else in charge, call in all doubtful loans, and be on safe ground again. That's what good it will do!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: How are you protecting your depositors? By making a lot of idiotic loans!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Take it easy, Clark.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You know Dickson as well as we do. He'll shut the doors before he gives up control.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: All right, let him! I'm sick and tired of hearing about him. If he wants to run the bank, let him do it. I don't want any part of it.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Say, you know, I found out something yesterday about hitting a golf ball. You've got to hit with the left hand, and from the inside out, it's the only way you can hit anything

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: I think, Mr. Dickson, we would like to have a little of your very valuable time here at the bank this morning, if you don't mind.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Oh, you would, eh?  All right. If it's more important than golf, go ahead. What's on your mind?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What's the matter with my policy? How many losses has this bank taken in the last twenty-five years?  I'll tell you. Not a single one!  What's wrong with that kind of banking?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Just pure luck!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Character, hmmpf! That's your idea?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Not at all. That's Alexander Hamilton's idea[5] - the finest banking mind this country has ever known. Those are his exact words, gentlemen. Character!  It's the only thing you can bank on, and it's the only thing that will pull this country out of the doldrums.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Most of the creditors I know personally. I've seen them grow up in the community. I knew their fathers and mothers before them.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: I know, Dickson. That's all very well. But you're taking too many chances. In these times a bank should keep liquid in case of trouble. In case of emergency!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I'm running this bank my way. Get that clear!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Gentlemen, you notice Mr. Dickson refuses to consider our wishes. He refuses an offer to merge with the New York Trust - the only thing that will put this bank on safe ground. He insists upon running a bank on so flimsy a thing as . . . as faith!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Yes! You said it, Clark. That's the only thing that means anything to me.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: We want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What about?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: We'll discuss that in the board room.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: We'll be forced to shut the doors. I've worked twenty-five years night and day to keep this bank alive. You've all made money out of it. Are you willing to help?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: What do you mean, help?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I know that among you, you have at least a million dollars in various banks throughout the city. Get that money over here and I'll stop this run within five minutes.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: That sounds very simple, Dickson, but why should we jeopardize our personal fortunes?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I have everything I own in it. It's your bank as well as mine, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: The depositors you were protecting were the first ones to pounce on you. You thought they were your friends. Why don't you go out there now and try and get some help from them?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Aw, they've gone crazy. You can't reason with a mob.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: No. You can't reason with anyone else when you're in a jam. We pleaded with you to keep liquid, but you wouldn't listen to us. You preached to us about faith and a lot of other rubbish. Now you want our help. You want us to throw a lot of cash into a bank that you've wrecked. All right. There's one way you can get it. Give us an option on your stock and resign as president.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: So, that's it, eh? You've waited a long time for this chance, haven't you?  Well, I'm not going to resign now - or ever.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Say, you can't do that

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I can't? You just wait and see. If that run doesn't stop within the next hour, I'll shut the doors. You know what that means? The bank examiner will step in tomorrow. You'll be forced to liquidate. I'll insist upon it. The depositors will be paid one hundred cents on the dollar. What's left you gentlemen can have. But I'll guarantee there won't be enough to pay your next month's garage bill.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Dickson, I'd like to talk to you about the bank.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: The bank. All right. Do anything you want with it.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Come out here you pawnbrokers - take a look at this!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: We've been waiting fifteen minutes

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You know what you can do with that! Come on, take a look at this! You'll see a demonstration of faith that's worth more than all the collateral in the world.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: I hope you don't mind me asking you a few questions, Mr. Cluett.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Of course, yes. Just what would you like to know, Inspector?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Where were you at twelve o'clock last night?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: That's very simple. I was home.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: That is simple, isn't it? I assume you can prove that if necessary.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Oh yes, of course. There was someone with me. A lady.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Looks like you're going to have no trouble at all. What was the lady's name, Mr. Cluett?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: If you don't mind, Inspector, I'd rather not say - that is, unless it becomes absolutely essential. You see, she's married.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: You understand?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Why, of course.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Somebody must be in good humor. He was humming "Mother Machree."

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: It's one of the boys from headquarters. He always sings "Mother Machree" whenever he's got good news. Looks like this case'll be settled in no time.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Stand back Inspector, or I'll shoot. Drop that gun.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: All right, Jack, all right.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Don't be a fool, Cluett. This is only going to make it worse for you.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Stand back, Inspector. Let me out of here, or I'll shoot you!

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What were you doing at Finlay's this morning?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: They took my keys yesterday. I went there to get them back.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I was crazy, I tell you, Mr. Dickson. I didn't know what I was doing. I wandered around in a daze. All I could think of was that they were going to kill me . . .  You'll stand by me, won't you, Mr. Dickson? You won't go back on me now, will you? I'll die if they send me to prison!

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Don't forget there's a dead watchman downstairs.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I didn't kill him! I had nothing to do with that, I tell you! I was home in my apartment last night - I can prove it!

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Claims he was there with a married woman. Doesn't want to mention her name.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: He won't believe it, Mr. Dickson. But it's the truth - honest it is. I was in my apartment last night - ask your wife - she

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Confessed! Cluett, in heaven's name, what got into you?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I don't know. It's all been like a crazy nightmare, Mr. Dickson.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What happened?  You're not a thief. How'd you get mixed up with these kind of people?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Gambling - I owed them a lot of money. Last week I lost over fifty thousand dollars!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Fifty thousand dollars!

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: But I didn't kill that man last night. Honest I didn't, Mr. Dickson!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What was my wife doing in your apartment last night?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Nothing, nothing, Mr. Dickson. Don't pay any attention to me. I don't know what I'm saying.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You just mentioned her name. What was she doing there? What was she doing in your apartment?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: She just came up for a drink. Just for a few minutes.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: She wasn't to blame, Mr. Dickson. It wasn't her fault. Honest, it wasn't. I begged her to come up. She didn't

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Get out, get out!

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: You know what we do to welchers, Cluett, don't you?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I know, I know, Dude. Oh, I must have been crazy! I lost my head completely!

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: That's your funeral. We've got fifty thousand dollars comin' to us.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I haven't got it.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Then what did you want to gamble for? If you'd have beat us out of fifty G's, you'd have been paid, wouldn't you? Well, we want our dough.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I'm sorry, Dude, butI

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: That don't do us any good.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: But after all, you can't take blood from a stone.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: We can take blood from anything   If it's comin' to us.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Good heavens, man! You're not suggesting that I

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Why, I couldn't do that . . . !

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: You don't have to do nothing.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: All you gotta do is fix a few things for us , and we'll do the rest, see?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Dude - there's not any chance of my becoming involved in this, is there?

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: You? No, you'll be all right, so long as you establish an alibi for tonight.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: know, but

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Be sure you're with somebody responsible in case any questions are asked. Understand?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: But Dude, listen - couldn't we make this some other time?

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Listen, buddy, you're getting by pretty easy. Quit squawking!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: This won't do. Not during business hours . . .

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Why, I needed a

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: What is the matter with you? You're trembling?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Am I? Why, I - I don't know any reason why I should be, unless of course it's you . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Being alone with you has always done this to me. You know that.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: For a celebrated bounder, that is an awful admission. Besides, I never knew that any female could do this to you .

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Well, you can. You always could.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Liar! You're just suffering from lack of sleep.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Here, here, here, now! Don't you go back to work on me, too. I'm getting tired of this. Besides, it's beginning to affect your looks

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: What is?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: running around. Not your work.  You'd better start reforming, Cyril!

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: If I thought you were the slightest bit interested, I would.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Not bad, not bad at all. Do you know something? I've always been curious about your line.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Line?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Whatever it is that makes you such a riot with women.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Come on Cyril, try a little bit of it out on me. I haven't had any first-class blarney thrown at me since the day I was married.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: But you see, it isn't blarney where you're concerned.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Now let me see, what comes next?  Oh yes, I know - what are you doing tonight, Phyllis?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Doesn't that come next?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Yes, yes, it does. What are you doing tonight, Phyllis?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: See, we're getting along famously!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Oh! Oh, no!  I think I've done enough experimenting for one day. Congratulations, Cyril. You've convinced me that you're a philanderer of the very first order. I shall recommend you highly.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Please, please don't laugh at me, Phyllis. I must see you tonight!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: But I'm giving a party for him - a real, old-fashioned surprise party. Caps, bells, whistles, and everything. I'm really terribly excited about it. I've been planning it for months.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Well

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Well, what?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Well, aren't you going to invite me?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: You? No can do. It's all set. Just a few of Tom's closest friends.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Now Phyllis, if you don't invite me, I'm coming anyway.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Don't be silly, Cyril. These are respectable people. They'd probably bore you to death.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: No, they won't. Not when you are there. Oh, please, be a sport. Please ask me.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Why are you so anxious?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Don't you know?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I want to be near you!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Don't you know I've been crazy about you for years?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Now wait a minute, wait a minute...

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I've loved you ever since I can remember, long before you married Tom Dickson.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Why, Cyril, you're insane

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: No. No, I'm not. I deliberately avoided you. I was afraid of making a fool of myself. But I won't stand it any longer

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Cyril!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: My apartment.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: I knew I couldn't trust you. You told me you were taking me home.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Come on up for just a few minutes. We'll have just one drink, then we'll go.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: No. I know the answer to that one.  I think you'd better take me home.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: What's the matter? Afraid papa will spank?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: No. No, I'm afraid papa isn't that much interested. He's too busy rushing off to Philadelphia to make stuffy, old speeches at stuffy, old bankers' meetings. Too busy closing big, important deals  I think I will have a drink.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Good for you. Come on.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: You know, there ought to be a Congressional Medal for men like you. America's comfort to misunderstood wives. I never thought I would find myself in that class.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Oh, you're not so badly off. There's something much worse than being a misunderstood wife.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: What is that, Mr. Bones?[7]

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: A misunderstood bachelor.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: And now fair woman, I have you in my power.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: I'm not afraid of you. You haven't got a moustache!

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I'll grow a moustache by the time you get out of here.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Why, Matt!

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Are the payrolls ready for tomorrow?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Let me see your cash book, will you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Yes, now.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: The butler said I could stay. I told him it was important.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Well, I thought I'd like to have a little talk with you.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I'm listening.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: It's funny - now that I'm here, I don't know just how to go about it.  You see, I kind of expected to find you here alone.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Anything you have to say to me, you can say in the morning.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Oh no, Mr. Cluett, if it's all the same to you, I'd rather not wait. It's about you and Mrs. Dickson.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I'm not interested in what you think.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: You've no right to do this to her, Mr. Cluett. Why don't you think it over? It's only gonna get you into a lot of trouble.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: I tell you, I'm not interested in your opinion.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: No?  Then maybe you'll understand, Mrs. Dickson. Oh, gee, he's crazy about you. Nobody knows it better than you. If he ever finds out, it'll kill him.

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: Phyllis, you don't have to explain anything.  You'd do well to mind your own business.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: This is my business. Mr. Dickson's been like a father to me.  What has he ever done to you to deserve a deal like this?

turns.speaker: CLUETT
turns.text: That will be just about enough! Now get out of here!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I guess I have said enough  I'm just wasting my breath talking to you.

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Dickson.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: John, how's your wife this morning?

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: Much better this morning, thank you.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Got a handkerchief?

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: Excuse me

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Wait a minute.  How do you feel this morning?

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: I'm feeling fine this morning.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: That makes it unanimous. I feel all right too.

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: Thank you!

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: Shall we let the people come in?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Of course, let them in! You're late now.

turns.speaker: GARDINER
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Dickson. My wife is much better this morning.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Well, that's too bad. Mine's all right too.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Well, look who's here! Hello, dear.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Hello, darling.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: If this isn't a red-letter day for Tom Dickson! First I trample on the Board of Directors, then I promote Matt here to assistant cashier, and now to complete the day I have a visit from my sweet and lovely and gorgeous wife. What a man, what a man!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: It's amazing that your sweet, lovely, gorgeous wife can ever get to see you.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Oooh! That has the earmarks!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What's the matter dear? What have I done now?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Nothing. Tom, I thought you were going out with me tonight.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Oh, I did have a date with you tonight, didn't I?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I'm terribly sorry. I'd forgotten all about you. I'm so sorry, dear.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Now Tom, you simply cannot go to Philadelphia tonight. That's all there is to it.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: But I have to go, dear. It's a very important banker's meeting.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: I don't care whether it's important or not. You said you were going out with me, and if you hadn't promised so faithfully, I wouldn't have gone and planned the whole thing.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Listen, it isn't so terribly important. We can go to the theatre any time.

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: The theatre?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: That's what it was you planned, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You can take some of the girls. You can take Mildred - or Gwynn

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: The girls!  I don't suppose it ever occurred to you that I might go out and find myself an attractive young man . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Ho! Ho! Ho!

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Ho, ho, ho, yourself! I wouldn't laugh if I were you. You may not suspect it, but I'm still attractive - to some.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Listen, don't go around being attractive to anyone but me . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Well . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Don't you forget that I'm still the head man around here too. Now we'll get the tickets changed for tomorrow night. You and I are going out together. How's that?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: All right. I'll postpone the whole thing until tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Happy now?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Listen, dear. I want to ask you something. I know it's a silly thing for me to ask you, but . . . I want you to tell me the truth. Where were you last night?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: Last night? Er - why - uh, last night . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Listen, dear. Now tell me the truth about this. Were you in Cluett's apartment?

turns.speaker: MRS. DICKSON
turns.text: In Cluett's apartment? Well dear, you see, I . . . I . . .

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Helen, you're becoming more beautiful every day. What are we going to do about it?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Guess we'll just have to sacrifice the bank. When are you and Matt going to get married?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Why - well, I

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Ummm. Stalling, eh?  Anything new?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Why, the directors are waiting for you in the board room.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Directors, eh? Long faces?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Longer.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I haven't got any new stories for them this morning, either.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Helen, tell Matt I want to see him.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Dickson - they're going to arrest Matt. They think he did it!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Where is he now?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: In Mr. Sampson's office.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Now don't you worry about it.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Come on in here, Helen. Bring your book. I want some numbers to try to get some action. Get Parker at the Union-Leeds - the Exchange . . . Winslow and old man Harris at the Home Mortgage. Snap into it, Helen. Just as quick as you can.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You want the rest of those numbers, Mr. Dickson?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Numbers? No, never mind.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Good morning, Helen.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Say, I know what's the matter with you. Matt!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Oh, no! It's not for you. You're only going to get married. Mrs. Dickson and I are going to go on the honeymoon.

turns.speaker: HELEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Helen, I'm going to Philadelphia, just as soon as the bank closes. Make all the arrangements, will you?

turns.speaker: HELEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: HELEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Mr. Sampson . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: All right. Send him in.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Helen!

turns.speaker: HELEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Get Mrs. Dickson on the phone.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Good morning, Mrs. Pembroke.

turns.speaker: MRS. PEMBROKE
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Dickson.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Got my letter?

turns.speaker: MRS. PEMBROKE
turns.text: Yes, thank you.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Hello, Helen.

turns.speaker: MRS. PEMBROKE
turns.text: Mr. Dickson?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Ah, Mrs. Pembroke. I spoke to Mr. Schaffer at the Guaranty. He's going to take care of that mortgage for you . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. PEMBROKE
turns.text: But, Mr. Dickson, I thought you were going to take care of the mortgage. I only want ten thousand. The property is worth sixty.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Mr. Schaffer will take good care of you. He'll give you fifteen - maybe twenty . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Wait a minute. Where's your uniform?

turns.speaker: JANITOR
turns.text: I haven't any.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You haven't got a uniform?

turns.speaker: JANITOR
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: My goodness, you ought to have a uniform. How much does one cost?

turns.speaker: JANITOR
turns.text: Why, I don't know.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You see Sampson. Tell him I sent you. You've got to have a uniform.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Oh, make that uniform blue.

turns.speaker: JANITOR
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Well, well, well - got your uniform, eh?

turns.speaker: JANITOR
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Looks good. How much did it cost?

turns.speaker: JANITOR
turns.text: I don't know. Mr. Sampson bought it for me.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: It's all right. Thanks.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: And what's more, keep up the good work and who knows - some day you'll be the fellow sitting behind that desk . . .  Not a bad thought, eh?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What's the matter? You don't seem very excited about it.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Sure, I think it's swell.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Say, come on. Show a little enthusiasm. What's the matter? Are you sick or something? Go on, fake it - even if it isn't real.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Aw, I'm sorry, Mr. Dickson. It's just kind of sudden, that's all.  Sure, I'm excited. I think it's great. Only, well, you've done so much for me already . . . I'll never be able to thank you enough.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Aw, go on, forget it. You came through, didn't you? That's all I wanted. A lot of them didn't think you would. You don't know how much satisfaction it's been to me. It's been swell. Well, when are you and Helen going to get married?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Well, I

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I suppose you want me to fix that up for you too, eh?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I already told him I was home.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: There you are.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Wait a minute. Wait a minute.  Matt, do you realize you're up against something? You're being charged with murder. It's serious, son. Now come on, I know you didn't do it.  But we've got to make them believe it. Come on, tell the truth, where were you last night?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I can't tell you.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: No. I won't.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: You're protecting somebody.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: No, I'm not Mr. Dickson!

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Yes, you are. You're protecting somebody. Now listen, it doesn't make any difference who it is. It can't be as important as this. Now come on, tell me. Where were you last night?  Come on, don't be a fool. Matt, you trust me, don't you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: We haven't got much time left, Mr. Dickson. We've got to do something quick or it'll be too late.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Why wouldn't you tell me where you were last night?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: You're not giving up, are you, Mr. Dickson?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Were you in Cluett's apartment?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Oh, I can explain about that later. You're losing your bank - don't you realize what that means?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Was Mrs. Dickson there?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Listen, Mr. Dickson, don't let them lick you just because a couple of big shots turned you down. You've got more friends than anybody in this town. Little guys - guys who wouldn't be in business if it weren't for you. All you've got to do is

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Wait a minute. Answer my question. Was Mrs. Dickson there?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Well . . . uh . . . I . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: She was, wasn't she? How long has this been going on? Do you know?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Aw, I don't know what you're talking about. All I know is that you're losing your bank and

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: All right. That's all.  Please, Matt.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I want you both to take the day off. Go downtown and get a license and get married right away!

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: But I haven't . . .

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: I don't want to hear any more about it. If you don't get married, I'll fire both of you.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Helen, while you're downtown, you might stop in and make reservations for the bridal suite on the Berengaria sailing next week.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Gee, thanks, Mr. Dickson

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What's the matter? What's going on here?  This is ridiculous! You can't hold this boy on a vague suspicion.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: I'm afraid I must, Mr. Dickson.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Why pick on him ?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: It's an inside job. That's a cinch. Whoever did it had a pretty good picture of the layout. Now Brown, here, is in charge of the vaults, isn't he?

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: What time did this thing happen?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: The clock opposite the vault was stopped by a bullet at 12:09.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: All right. If the boy proves an alibi, he's all right, isn't he?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: If he can do it, yes.

turns.speaker: DICKSON
turns.text: Why, certainly he can.  Matt, now all you've got to do is tell them where you were last night, between twelve and twelve-thirty, and everything will be all right.
